answers.answer: The Optomap (which I don't use) is for looking at the back of the eye. I don't think its used to check IOP which usually uses a Goldman tomometer or tonopen.The most important thing with IOP that high would be to be sure there is no angle closure glaucoma. If there was an urgent referral to an Eye MD would be needed.If the angles were open the person would need a glaucoma work up including: gonioscopy, visual fields, corneal pachymetery, optic nerve OCT, dilated exam,and careful follow upJCH MD

question: Dr Hagan,A 46 yr old Caucasian female with history of major depression, agoraphobia, CFS, Fibromyalgia, lower extremities neuropathy, hypertension, Type 2 diabetes, diet controlled after Roux en Y WLS 5 years prior, GERD, history of farsightedness; family history 1 sister with insulin dependent type II DM & cataracts, mother with wet macular degeneration & is legally blind, strong family history of hypertension & moderate history of CAD. Presents with an IOP per optomap of 31 OD 28 OS & 24 OD 27 OS  30 minutes later. No dilatation done. Optometrist has never seen patient before. Other than increasing reading glasses from 0.5 to 1.75, optometrist does nothing else and plans to recheck IOP in one year. Agree or disagree?
title: elevated IOP treatment scenario
